video:video.video:title: Can F-1 Visa International Students Work While in School?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Can F-1 Visa International Students Work While in School?
Optional Practical Training
One way that international students can work while studying abroad is through the Optional Practical Training (OPT) program. In order to do this, they must be an F-1 student, and the work must be directly related to the area of study for that particular student. If an international student is eligible for OPT, they can be authorized for employment for up to twelve months before they complete their education and/or after. It is important to note however that if OPT work is done after the education is received, any amount of OPT performed before the completion of education is deducted from that twelve months. For example, if an international student worked for eight months before they completed their studies through OPT, then that student could only be authorized for four months of OPT work after completing their studies.
On Campus Employment
Perhaps the easiest way for an international student to gain employment while studying abroad is to work on campus. On campus work is defined as work that is on the institution's campus or on the property of an institution that is educationally affiliated with the primary institution. An example of on campus work would include an on campus commercial business (such as the campus bookstore). The work MUST be affiliated with the institution and provide service to the students of the institution. Work for an educationally affiliated institution not on the property would be allowed, such as working in a research lab.
What are the Requirements?
There are three requirements for on-campus work:
The job must not displace a United States Citizen, An international student can work a maximum of twenty hours per week while school is in session, but may work full time while school is not in session or on a vacation/break. An international student must report their work to a designated school official and have a certification letter to show to the Social Security Administration in order to have a Social Security Number.
Severe Economic Hardship Most students who work while in school, both international and domestic, work because they need the money. If you are an international student and need financial assistance, along with working there are also many options for international student loans. An example of severe economic hardship would include unforeseen medical bills or some other vast, unforeseen expense that the student has incurred. If an international student meets the criteria for this category, they then must apply for an employment authorization document. The application can then take up to twelve weeks, maybe even longer. Work cannot be started without this document. Once the international student's F-1 status has expired, the authorization to work terminates.
Along with part time work, there are other options for funding international student education in the United States. There are several lenders that may serve international students, and Nomad Credit can connect international students to them. For more information, visit www.nomadcredit.com. We will happily help you find the best option for education loans or study loans. If you have any questions, send an email to help@nomadcredit.com and we will happily help!

video:video.video:title: Work Options for J-1 Visa International Students in the United States
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Recently, we discussed work opportunities for international students studying abroad in the United States on F-1 visas. Today, we will explore the options available for those in the United States on J-1 visas. International students who are in the United States on J-1 visas differ from those on F-1 visas because those on J-1 visas are typically research scholars, professors, and exchange students, rather than students as is typical for F-1 visas. They still participate in educational programs, but their purpose in the United States is more to receive training, normally in the business and medical fields.
Work Opportunities for Non-Sponsor
Typically, the United States only authorizes international students on J-1 visas to have employment through their program sponsors. So, if there is a professor who holds a J-1 visa to teach at the University of Florida, that professor can typically only be authorized for that position at the University of Florida. However, there are some cases and situations where a J-1 visa holder could be authorized to work for a non-sponsor employer.
One of these ways is through a closely related research program. A J-1 visa holder could work for a non-sponsor if that position is with a research program, which is closely related to the program that the original J-1 visa was authorized for. However, the visa holder could only hold that position for a maximum of six months. Also, before the visa holder starts their employment at that research program, they must receive written authorization from their original J-1 visa sponsor.
The other situations in which a J-1 visa holder can find employment through a non-sponsor include:
On-campus employment, Off-campus employment, Serious economic hardship experienced while under the J-1 status, Exceptional academic standing, The hours of work must not exceed 20 hours per week. Also, college students along with graduate students can become eligible for a practical training program. This program would extend the J-1 status up to eighteen months for student's pursuing bachelor's and master's degrees, and would extend status for thirty-six months for students pursing a doctoral degree. Those who seek approval for a practical training program must apply for it.
Types of Non-Sponsor Employment
In order for a J-1 visa holder to find employment on campus through a non-sponsor employer (such as a cafeteria), the employment has to be pursuant to a scholarship, fellowship, or assistantship. Since there are many different requirements to qualify for a J-1 visa, it must fall under one of those for on-campus employment.
J-1 visas holders can also find non-sponsor employment off-campus in some situations. One of these situations is if the visa holder is in the United States on a summer work or travel exchange program. The other situation is if while in the United States, the visa holder suffers severe, unforeseen economic hardship. For all of the above situations, the visa holder must receive the proper authorization. If authorized for any type of non-sponsor work, the visa holder may only work a maximum of twenty hours per week, and must have excellent academic standing.
What About a Spouse or Child?
For spouses and/or children of J-1 visas holders, there is the J-2 visa. This visa is intended for spouses or children to accompany or even later join the J-1 visa holder. However, not all J-1 programs allow for J-2 eligibility. For example, the camp counselor J-1 program does not allow for J-2 eligibility. If the visa holder has eligibility for a J-2 accompaniment, they must also receive approval from the sponsor of the J-1 program.
For the most part, J-2 visa holders can work while in the United States. In order to do so, the J-2 visa holder must receive and Employment Authorization Document before employment can be started. Unfortunately, any income or monies earned by a J-2 visa holder may not be used to support the J-1 visa holder.
Along with part time work, there are other options for funding international student education in the United States. There are several lenders that may serve international students, and Nomad Credit can connect international students to them. For more information, visit www.nomadcredit.com. We will happily help you find the best option for education loans or study loans. If you have any questions, send an email to help@nomadcredit.com and we will happily help!

video:video.video:title: Top Artificial Intelligence Programs in the U.S.
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Many international students come to the U.S. to attain a Master of Science in Computer Science. A specialization of Computer Science that is gaining traction and being pursued is Artificial Intelligence.
Simply put, Artificial Intelligence is intelligence demonstrated by machines. A subset of computer science, the field of Artificial Intelligence is the study of “intelligent agents”: any machine that observes its environment and initiates steps that optimize its chance of success at some goal or task. Informally, Artificial Intelligence is applied when machines or computers mimic cognitive functions or behaviors that would typically be associated with a human mind, such as problem solving, learning or pattern recognition.
Artificial Intelligence continues to grow in step with other advances in technology. Many universities are offering programs to provide companies like Google and IBM valuable team members to further their Artificial Intelligence endeavors. A close cousin to Artificial Intelligence is Machine Learning, which we profiled the top programs in Machine Learning last month.
The top graduate Artificial Intelligence programs in the United States, according to U.S. news are:
Stanford University Carnegie Mellon University Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) University of California – Berkeley University of Washington Georgia Tech University of Illinois – Urbana-Champaign University of Texas – Austin Cornell University University of California – Los Angeles (UCLA) University of Michigan – Ann Arbor University of Massachusetts – Amherst Columbia University University of Pennsylvania University of Southern California (USC) California Institute of Technology (Caltech) University of Maryland – College Park University of Wisconsin – Madison Please do your own research for each individual school to make sure that a specific Artificial Intelligence program is the best fit for you. It can depend upon a lot of factors such as location, relationships with companies, school culture, faculty members, research funding, etc. We've found one of the best ways to know if the program is a good fit is to get to know the faculty that you would be learning and working with during your time at the program. Another good way to research is to reach out to the international alumni of the program so that they can share their experience of attending school and finding a job after.
To get the most up-to-date and accurate information about a particular program and information on the process of applying please contact the admissions of the universities that you are interested in exploring.
The above list of programs certainly is not exhaustive, we recommend that international students research all schools fully. If you know of any U.S. universities that have specializations in Artificial Intelligence please contribute below in the comments.
Please look for a blog about the job prospects, career choices and the companies that are hiring international students in the Artificial Intelligence field soon.
We will have more in depth profiles of individual Masters in Computer Science programs at these schools in the future. Which ones do you want to see the most? Please let us know in the comments.
As always, please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com to search for your financial product options, including education loans and student health insurance. Please don't hesitate to email us at help@nomadcredit.com.

video:video.video:title: Application Proccess for Partner Sites on Nomad Credit
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains how the application process on our lender partner's sites work for international students once they receive an option after filling out a product search.
After you fill in your search you will receive options based upon the information you submitted. From there you can select the lender option that you would like to explore. Clicking "Select" will take you to the lender partner site where you can fill out an application. After filling out the application you will know if you are eligible for a product from our lender partner.
For an example, we go into how Prodigy Finance's application process works at https://blog.nomadcredit.com/what-is-the-process-to-apply-for-an-education-loan-from-prodigy-finance/
If you have not already searched for an education loan or study loan, please come visit us at www.nomadcredit.com. Please don't hesitate to email us at help@nomadcredit.com with any questions that you may have.

video:video.video:title: What is the WES Evaluation?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com.
Nate from Nomad Credit explains how the WES Evaluation works for international students on F1 visas or J1 visas and H1B Visa holders coming to the U.S.
WES stands for the World Education Services and they will take your academic documents from your home country, analyze them, and create a profile that shows what the U.S. equivalent would be.
This can be very helpful for U.S. universities and employers who are looking at international students to admit or foreign nationals to hire.
It is something to think about exploring as allowing U.S. universities or companies to get a better picture of your skills can only help you.
We'd be happy to help you search for an education loan or study loan, please come visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com. Please don't hesitate to email us at help@nomadcredit.com with any questions that you may have.

video:video.video:title: International Student: Statement of Purpose Tips
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains what a Statement of Purpose is and what universities are looking for when an international student writes one.
Please Share if you've found this helpful!
If you need help searching for financial products such as student loans or education loans please come visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com.

video:video.video:title: International Students: How to Pick a Program at a U.S. University
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains how to go about picking the best program as an international student.
He suggests that the best program for you is one that fits you the best. Once you know what you would like to study and what you hope to get out of attending a university in the United States, start looking at some university rankings to get an idea of how good a school may be.
Then compare your credentials to what a school generally requires so that you can narrow down your choice to schools you have a chance of getting into. Once you've done that, reach out to the schools admissions and the specific program department that you are interested in to get more information about the program to see if it fits your criteria. At this point you can also begin reaching out to alumni of a certain school to see what their experiences were.
Ultimately the best school is the school that is the best fit for your goals and aspirations. It takes research to and correspondence with a school and their alumni to fully vet a school to see if they are a good fit.
Once you are admitted to your school please let us know if you need any help finding financial products, such as education loans, please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com.

video:video.video:title: What is a Financial Marketplace?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains what a financial marketplace is. Nomad Credit is a financial marketplace for F1 visa and J1 visa international students and H1B visa holders that are living or planning to live in the United States.
Financial marketplaces connect consumers to the online lenders and financial institutions that will serve them. Nomad Credit connects international students and visa holders to the few online lenders that will serve to that subset of consumers.
For more information please check out our blog post about online lending and financial marketplaces: https://blog.nomadcredit.com/online-lending-and-financial-marketplaces-a-guide-for-international-students-and-visa-holders/
As always, please visit https://www.nomadcredit.com to search for the financial products that you need such as education loans or study loans, or student medical insurance.

video:video.video:title: When Should International Students Search for an Education Loan?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains when an international student on an F1 or J1 visa is looking for education loan or study loan options, they likely will need to know which schools they will be admitted too.
Our lender partners will require admission and proof into a certain university before they can see if you are eligible for a loan from them.
It may make sense to wait until you are admitted into certain universities to start the loan search process.
When you know what university you are planning to go to or admitted to, please visit us at Nomad Credit and we'd be happy to help you with your education loan search.

video:video.video:title: When should International Students apply to a School for a Scholarship?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains that it is best for international students to apply early in the school application process so that they may have the best chance to be awarded a scholarship.
Scholarships usually have limited funds to award to students for a given academic year. Often, scholarships will require that a student know where they are going to attend school before they can award money to that student. Because of this, it is best to know where you are going to school as soon as it is possible. Otherwise, the scholarship funds available for a certain scholarship may already have been given out and you will miss out on funding.
If you are an international student on an F1 visa or J1 visa that needs to search for other sources of funding for your education in the US, such as education loans, please come visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com and we'd be happy to help you out!

video:video.video:title: What's the difference between the IELTS and the TOEFL English Tests?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains the basic differences between the IELTS and the TOEFL non-native English speaker proficiency tests for international students.
International students on an F1 visa or J1 visa coming to study in the U.S. will likely need to take one or the other before coming to school in the U.S.
Both tests look at four skills: Reading, Speaking, Writing, and Listening.
The IELTS is more focused on educational, immigration and occupational based purposes of English whereas the TOEFL is more focused on academic, university and classroom based purposes.
The IELTS is created and administered by a UK institution, and thus is somewhat preferred by UK universities.
The TOEFL is created and administered by a US institution, and thus is somewhat preferred by US universities.
However, both are accepted by thousands of universities and other educational institutions around the world and likely either one would be fine. Please research the universities you are considering to see which test they will accept.
If you have any additional questions about the IELTS and the TOEFL tests, please let us know in the comments below!
As always, please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com to search for education loans or study loans.

video:video.video:title: Education Loan Cosigner Responsibility
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Brian from Nomad Credit explains that the cosigner on an education loan for an international student needs to be aware of the serious responsibility that they may have.
If the international student is able to pay the education loan or study loan on time, then the cosigner would bear no responsibility.
However, If it becomes the case where the international student is unable to pay back the education loan, the cosigner would be liable for the balance of the loan. The lender or bank will likely make the cosigner pay back the loan or take ownership of a cosigner's assets to make the loan whole.
When finding a cosigner, it is definitely important to think about what kind of responsibility they are taking on and if they are willing and able to do so.
Whether you have a cosigner or not, please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com and we can help you search and compare the education loan or study loan options that you may have.

video:video.video:title: University Application Deadlines: What an International Student Needs to Know
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains what an international student needs to know about applying to U.S. Universities.
U.S. Universities will have deadlines for applying to their schools. Each university is a little different, so it is best to research the schools directly so that you can know all of the relevant information needed in terms of deadlines and what materials are required to apply.
Many schools will have a deadline in early November, so applying in September or October is a good bet.
One thing to remember, many universities will have more than one round of applications. They may have a deadline in November, and then the second deadline in January, and even a third in the Spring.
The best chance to get into a university is to apply early.
After you get into a university, if you need help finding funding options for your education please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com to search and compare education loan options for international students on F1 visa or J1 visas.

video:video.video:title: International Students: Online Lending
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Brian from Nomad Credit explains how online lending is very popular in the United States and could be an option to consider for international students who need financial products such as an education or study loan.
Online lending can be more convenient as it takes less time and you can do it from the comfort of your own home. Online lenders can let you know if you are eligible for a loan without you needing to go to a bank and turn in paper documents.
Nomad Credit has partnered with online lenders and banks to create a great online experience for finding financial products.
Nomad Credit is a great option for international students on an F1 visa or J1 visa to search for the financial products they need. Please visit us today to search for education loans or study loans, and student medical insurance.

video:video.video:title: Scholarship Options for International Students
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Brian from Nomad Credit explains how scholarships can be a good option for international students to help fund their education in the United States.
Scholarships should be the first option that an international student on an F1 or J1 visa should look for to help fund your studies after you are admitted to a school.
Scholarships are free and you don't have to pay them back unlike an education or study loan. So our advice is to search for scholarship opportunities from your university, organizations in the U.S. or organizations in your own country.
After you've looked into scholarships, we would be more than happy to help you find education loans or study loans to help fund the rest of your education.

video:video.video:title: International Students: The Importance of a Cosigner
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Brian from Nomad Credit explains the importance of a cosigner for international students on F1 or J1 visas when searching for education loan or study loan options.
Not all student lenders will require a cosigner, but many do. Having a cosigner, either in the U.S. or from a home country, will open up more options for an international student that is seeking an education loan.
Nomad Credit works with lenders that do not require a cosigner, so even if you don't have one, we may be able to find you an option. But having a cosigner will allow you the best chance to receive a loan option from one of our partners.
So come visit Nomad Credit at https://www.nomadcredit.com/student-loans today to see what education loan or study loan options you may have!

video:video.video:title: International Students: Professional vs. Academic Masters
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains the difference between a professional masters program and an academic (or research) masters program to international students planning to study in the U.S. on an F1 visa or J1 visa.
A professional masters program prepares international students with the skills they need to join the workforce immediately after graduating. This would provide the skills needed to go out into the field of that certain discipline.
An academic masters is usually a step towards pursuing a career in academia, exploring the philosophy behind the field and doing research to expand on the field's knowledge. Often, an academic masters degree is a precursor to attaining a PhD degree in a certain field. International students seeking a career in academia will often become researchers or professions and be employed by universities
As always, please visit Nomad Credit for all of your financial needs, if you need to find options for education loans or study loans, student medical insurance, please visit us! https://www.nomadcredit.com

video:video.video:title: Building Credit: Why It Is Important For International Students
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Brian from Nomad Credit explains why building credit is important for international students. International student may want to start thinking about building credit when they come to the U.S. to study.
Most financial products, such as personal loans, mortgages, or auto loans require credit history in order to be eligible for a loan. Not only that, but lenders will look at how good your credit history may be to determine the rates that you may get.
So it is important to start now so you can set yourself up well in the future when you need other financial products.
Nomad Credit is a great place to search for financial products for an international student with an F1 Visa or J1 Visa. Nomad Credit has a credit card partner that will give out a credit card to international students if they qualify without requiring credit history. This will allow you to start building your credit today.
Please visit us to search for your credit card options and other financial products such as education loans or study loans.

video:video.video:title: International Students: What does STEM mean?
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Nate from Nomad Credit explains what is considered a STEM major. Many international students coming to the U.S. are STEM majors. STEM stands for Science, Tech, Engineering, and Mathematics.
The U.S. Government projects there will be 1.2 million STEM jobs by 2018 but not enough STEM graduates to fill all of them up. International students coming here on an F1 Visa or J1 Visa can help fill that shortage.
Please visit http://www.nomadcredit.com to search for education or study loans and student health insurance. We can help international students on F1 visas or J1 visas find the financial options they need.

video:video.video:title: International Students: Student Medical Insurance Overview
video:video.video:description:
Most universities require their international students have student medical insurance (also known as student health insurance). A lot of universities will offer their international students a health insurance option as well.
However, many universities do not require that their international students use the university's health insurance option. This allows international students the ability to choose among private options, which may be cheaper than the university plan.
One of our partners, TaiAn Financial, is a private option. We'd be happy to connect you to TaiAn to see if they have an option that will fit your university and your visa type, J1 visa or F1 visa. For more information about TaiAn Financial, please visit our blog: https://blog.nomadcredit.com/taian-financial-student-health-insurance/
Please check us out at http://www.nomadcredit.com to find out if TaiAn Financial may be able to help you with your student medical insurance.

video:video.video:title: International students: How to Research US Universities
video:video.video:description:
Nate from Nomad Credit explains that the best way for international students to research universities is to visit specific school websites.
International students on F1 Visas or J1 Visas will be able to find the most up-to-date and accurate information about the university, their program, the cost of attendance, and job opportunities.
As always, please visit us at http://www.nomadcredit.com to search for your financial product options, including education loans or study loans and student health insurance. Please don't hesitate to email us at help@nomadcredit.com.

video:video.video:title: International Students: Getting a Good Job
video:video.video:description:
Brian from Nomad Credit explains some tips for international students to better their chances to gain a good job after graduating from a U.S. university.
For those international students needing an education loan or study loan to help fund their studies at Indiana University, please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com. We also can help you find student medical insurance options. We are more than happy to help and if you have any questions, please email us at help@nomadcredit.com.

video:video.video:title: International Students - Choosing your U.S. University
video:video.video:description:
As an international student it's important to take into account the location of your U.S. university in relation to job prospects of that area when choosing your school.
Oftentimes, the companies that are based in cities near your university will look to hire from those programs. So it's important to think about where your university is located, especially as an international student in the U.S.
Have any additional questions? Please comment below!
Visit our site at www.nomadcredit.com to search for all of your financial product needs.

video:video.video:title: International Students: US Central Bank Rates
video:video.video:description:
https://www.nomadcredit.com
Brian from Nomad Credit explains how the difference in a country's central bank rates could affect the rate you can receive on your education or study loan as an international student. Lenders based in different countries will be able to lend at certain rates depending on the rates of their country's central bank.
For instance, the U.S. central bank rate is currently lower than India's. Thus, education loans or study loans from a U.S.-based lender may be a cheaper option.
As always, please visit us for all of your financial product needs, such as education loans or study loans, or student medical insurance for international students who are studying in the U.S. on an F1 visa or J1 visa.

video:video.video:title: International Students: The STEM Shortage in the U.S.
video:video.video:description:
Nate from Nomad Credit explains the STEM shortage in the U.S. and how that may affect international students ability to gain a job.
Many international students coming to study in the U.S. choose to pursue a Masters of Science degree. This can be a good choice, partly because the chances to gain employment after graduating are high.
One reason for this is that there is a shortage of STEM majors in the U.S. As technology and the sciences continue to grow, the jobs that correspond with those industries are also growing.
Furthermore, this shortage is not going away. As of 2014-2015, there were an additional 230,246 STEM jobs and yet only 30,835 additional STEM graduates. STEM graduates are in hot demand.
To see more information about the STEM shortage view our blog post: https://blog.nomadcredit.com/international-students-job-prospects-for-a-masters-of-science-degree/
Want to find education loan options for student visa holders in the US, both F1 and J1 Visa holders? Come visit us at www.nomadcredit.com/student-loans to find your education loan options today.

video:video.video:title: Nomad Credit: Chicago City Life
video:video.video:description:
Brian from Nomad Credit talks about Chicago City Life, especially the summer in Chicago. There are a lot of great universities in Chicago, such as Northwestern University, University of Chicago, Depaul University, and University of Illinois.
The type of campus and in turn the city it is in is important in deciding which U.S. university to attend for international students.
It is important think about what type of campus you may want as you'll be in a new place and in a new country as an F1 visa or J1 visa holder.
Have any additional questions on city life in Chicago? Please let us know in the comments below!
Check us out at www.nomadcredit.com to search for all of your financial product needs, including education loans and student health insurance.

video:video.video:title: International Students: Are Multiple Education Loans Okay?
video:video.video:description:
Brian from Nomad Credit explains if is possible to receive multiple loans from different lender sources.
Some international students cannot cover the cost of their attendance just with one education (aka student) loan. It is more than acceptable to receive an education loan from more than one lender.
Want to find education loan options for student visa holders in the US, both F1 and J1 Visa holders? Come visit us at www.nomadcredit.com/student-loans to find your education loan options today.

video:video.video:title: International Students: Financial Proof Required For US Universities
video:video.video:description:
Nate from Nomad Credit explains what US universities will allow for financial proof of funds on the Form I-20. International students coming to the U.S. on an F1 visa or J1 visa need to show proof of funding for the cost of one full year attending their school of choice.
Generally, universities will accept scholarships, personal loans, education loans (also known as student loans), and any proof of personal or family income or sponsorship.
For more in-depth information please visit our blog at: https://blog.nomadcredit.com/international-students-know-what-financial-sources-u-s-universities-will-accept-for-the-i-20/
As always, please visit us at https://www.nomadcredit.com to search for your financial product options, including education loans and student health insurance. Please don't hesitate to email us at help@nomadcredit.com.

video:video.video:title: Introduction to College Sports in U.S.
video:video.video:description:
Brian from Nomad Credit explains how college sports are a big part of the university experience in the U.S. This may be a relatively unknown thing for international students coming to the U.S. to study.
College sports can be a large part of a university's culture depending on the school. American football and basketball have a large following and a lot of the students will attend the events. College sports can provide a great addition to the university experience.
We have the College World Series going on right now, you should check it out.
Check us out at www.nomadcredit.com to search for all of your financial product needs, including education loans and student health insurance.
